data.title: Times Top10: Today's Top News Headlines and Latest News from India & across the World
data.meta_description: Check today's top 10 news stories, headline news, breaking news, latest news, politics news, sports news, entertainment news and business news on Times of India
data.text:
What

The Supreme Court on Monday has directed the CBI to submit a report indicating the status of investigation.

The judges have also directed the NTA to approve the time duration between occurrence of question paper leak and conduct of exam on May 5.

The bench was hearing close to 30 petitions seeking a direction to conduct the exam afresh on grounds such as paper leak, OMR sheet manipulation, impersonation and cheating.

The next hearing will take place on July 11.

Key observations

Solicitor General Tushar Mehta appearing for the NTA said that the top 100 candidates are distributed among 95 sectors, in 56 cities, spread out in 18 states and UTs. He added that it is a “local malpractice”.

To this, the CJI asserted, “One thing is very clear. [Question paper] Leak has taken place.”

“The fact that the sanctity of the exam is compromised is beyond question. Now how wide is the leak?” he added.

The CJI underscored that it is important to determine the extent of the leak before a re-test is ordered. "Cancellation will be the last resort," he said.

Next steps

NTA has been directed by the CJI to clarify on the basis of information available as on (1) when the leak of question papers took place, (2) manner in which papers were leaked/disseminated, and (3) time duration between leak and actual conduct of exam.

NTA has been asked to make disclosures on (1) the steps which were taken by NTA to identify centres/cities where leak took place, (2) modalities followed for identifying them and (3) number of students who have so far been identified to be beneficiaries.

Also

The Supreme Court Monday rejected the West Bengal government’s plea challenging the Calcutta High Court order of a Central Bureau of Investigation (CBI) probe into allegations of crimes against women and land grabbing in Sandeshkhali.

“Why should the state be interested in protecting someone?” court observed. More here

Govt safe

Jharkhand CM Hemant Soren comfortably won the trust vote on Monday.

He got 45 votes in the 76-member state Assembly.

The 30-member Opposition staged a walkout.

This was the fourth floor test in Jharkhand since January 2020.

Why it matters

Soren was arrested on January 31 in a money laundering case tied to an alleged land scam.

He got bail after five months on June 28.

The 48-year-old took oath as CM on July 4, within a week of getting bail.

Monday’s floor test proved that the coalition government led by his JMM is not tottering.

Fewer MLAs

The Jharkhand Assembly has a full strength of 81 members.

However, it is down to 76 as four MLAs (two each from BJP and JMM) were elected to the Lok Sabha, and one (Hemant’s sister-in-law Sita Soren) resigned before joining BJP this March.

Cabinet formed

Former CM Champai Soren, who resigned on July 3 to facilitate Soren’s takeover, took oath as a minister in his new Cabinet.

Ten other leaders also took oath as ministers on Monday.

Congress’s Jamtara MLA Irfan Ansari, Mahagama MLA Deepika Pandey Singh and JMM’s Latehar MLA Baidynath Ram, who was excluded from the Champai Soren Cabinet, have been given berths.

‘Thanks, Champai’

Hemant Soren made a special mention of Champai Soren who ran the coalition government in his absence.

The CM said, “Main Champai Soren ji ko dhanyavad dena chahoonga, jinhone sarkar ko chalaya bhi aur bachaya bhi (I would like to thank Champai Soren who not only ran the government but also saved it).”

Crackdown

Delhi Police are utilising the recently enacted Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita (BNS) to dismantle criminal syndicates operating within the city.

So far, seven FIRs have been registered under the new law, with at least 11 individuals booked for their involvement in these criminal operations.

Crime hotspots

The cases were registered at police stations in Amar Colony, Govindpuri, Jaitpur, Jamia Nagar, Pul Prahladpur, Sarita Vihar and Hazrat Nizamuddin.

These targeted gangs involved in various crimes, including snatching, theft, robbery, illegal possession of firearms, gambling and threatening citizens.

The focus of these investigations is to dismantle organised criminal groups.

New law

BNS empowers them to take action against Section 111 (organised crime) and targets a range of offences, including kidnapping, robbery, cyber-crimes, and more.

Section 2 of 111 outlines the harshest punishment: death or life imprisonment with a fine of Rs 10 lakh if the offence results in death.

For other scenarios, the subsections specify varying minimum and potentially extended sentences, and Section 112 (petty organised crime), which carries a punishment of imprisonment for a term of at least one year, which can extend up to seven years.

Cases

In Jamia Nagar police station, two men were booked for running an organised crime syndicate with their associates.

The FIR that was registered on the complaint of a cop read, “The syndicate has managed to instil a sense of fear in the minds of the general public due to their criminal activities. As a result, nobody is willing to depose against them openly.”

It further read that the current legal, penal and procedural frameworks have proven inadequate to curb or control the threat posed by this syndicate. They were booked under Section 112 of BNS.

In another FIR, Govindpuri police team booked two history-sheeters with a record of over 50 criminal cases.

These individuals were involved in theft, snatching and carrying illegal weapons to intimidate the public.

The other FIRs also mentioned similar situations that had led to public fear, necessitating their booking under the new laws.

Submerged

Heavy rains have hit Mumbai and its surrounding areas in the last 24 hours leading to widespread waterlogging and disruption of suburban train services.

Some areas in the city have recorded over 300 mm of rainfall within six hours from 1 am to 7 am.

The India Meteorological Department (IMD) has issued an orange alert for Mumbai, Thane, Palghar and the Konkan belt.

Vikhroli's Veer Savarkar Marg Municipal School and MCMCR Powai saw the highest rainfall in the last 24 hours with over 315 mm of rainfall recorded.

Disruption

Over 50 flights have been cancelled due to the downpour.

Several airlines took to X to warn passengers and urged them to check flight status before leaving for the airport.

Visuals from across the city showed people wading through waist-deep waters and cars lined bumper to bumper on Mumbai roads.

All government, private and municipal schools and colleges have been shut across the city.

At Dombivli station, people waited for trains on submerged tracks.

Water-logging was reported from Worli, Buntara Bhavan, in Kurla East, King's Circle area of Mumbai, Dadar and Vidyavihar Railway Station.

Over 30 lakh commuters use the suburban local train services in Mumbai and neighbouring Thane, Palghar and Raigad every day.

Animals displaced

More than 30 animals, birds and reptiles were rescued in Mumbai and surrounding districts as heavy rains pounded the region.

Cases of lost and abandoned pets, strays, and domestic animals were also reported, along with wildlife distress calls from the city and suburbs, reported The Hindu.

No stopping

The IMD has predicted more rains for the city over this week.

Fairly widespread to widespread light to moderate rainfall, accompanied by thunderstorms and lightning, is expected over Konkan & Goa, Madhya Maharashtra, Kerala and Mahe, Lakshadweep, and Coastal Karnataka, IMD said.

Scattered to fairly widespread light to moderate rainfall is likely over Marathwada, Gujarat Region, Coastal Andhra Pradesh & Yanam, Telangana, and Interior Karnataka.

Moderate rain is expected over Tamil Nadu, Puducherry & Karaikal, and Rayalaseema during the next five days.

Over to Centre

The Supreme Court on Monday refused to consider a plea seeking menstrual leave for female employees.

The court, however, has instructed the central government to engage in discussions with all relevant stakeholders and states to formulate a model policy on this matter.

Flip side

A bench led by CJI D Y Chandrachud said that while the policy may encourage women’s participation in the workforce, the flip side to it is that it may dissuade employers from engaging women.

It’s a policy decision which can be attended to by the Centre and state governments, the SC said.

Same stand

This is not the first time the SC has taken such a stance.

In February, it had refused to entertain a PIL that sought to compel all states to establish rules for granting menstrual pain leave to female students and working women at their respective workplaces.

The court had observed that this issue falls within the policy domain of the government.

Law in 2 states

The petitioner in the case had highlighted that only two states in India, Bihar and Kerala, currently provide menstrual leave for women.

In 1992, during Lalu Prasad Yadav’s tenure as CM, Bihar introduced two days of paid menstrual leave for female employees.

More recently, on January 19, Kerala CM Pinarayi Vijayan announced a three-day period leave for female students in the state.

Surprising turn

The leftist New Popular Front (NFP) emerged with the highest number of seats in the national assembly, followed by President Emmanuel Macron’s alliance.

But no single alliance won a working majority.

Tough negotiations started Monday as France faced a hung parliament.

Possibilities

The NFP could form a minority government or become part of a large but unwieldy coalition, reported Reuters.

But one of NFP’s more divisive leaders, Jean-Luc Melenchon, ruled out any scope for a coalition.

"The president must appoint as prime minister someone from the New Popular Front to implement the NFP's programme, the whole programme and nothing but the programme," he told TV channel France 2.

The centrists, however, are open to negotiate, added Reuters.

Left’s agenda

The bloc’s key proposals included raising the minimum wage, reversing the pension reform introduced by Macron and capping key goods’ prices, said Reuters.

These, however, would likely not get greenlit in parliament without backdoor negotiations, it added.

Instability

The results left France, the euro-zone’s second largest economy, in limbo just weeks before the Paris Olympics.

This could likely weaken the country’s role in the EU.

It could also make pushing domestic agendas difficult.

On Monday, the euro fell by as much as 0.4%.

Chin up, Macron

Some experts believe Macron came out of the snap elections with his credibility intact, reported Euronews.

"He will be less weakened than we had expected and France will continue to be able to exercise its international role with a certain panache, as it has done until now," Federico Santopinto, director at French think tank IRIS, told the news agency.

What about the far-right?

National Rally leader Jordan Bardella called the cooperation between the left and the centre a “disgraceful alliance” that would paralyse the country.

But Marine Le Pen is hopeful. "Our victory has been merely delayed," she said.

What

Boeing is willing to plead guilty to a criminal fraud conspiracy charge in order to settle a US Justice Department investigation connected to two fatal 737 MAX crashes in 2018-19.

It will also pay a criminal fine of $243.6 million (Rs 2,033 crore), and invest at least $455 million over the next three years to strengthen its safety and compliance programmes.

The plea, which must be approved by a federal judge, would label the aircraft manufacturer as a convicted felon.

Why

The plea would facilitate the company’s efforts to move forward as it seeks approval for its planned acquisition of Spirit AeroSystems, especially with a new CEO set to take the helm later this year.

The plea agreement will allow Boeing to avoid a trial that could subject the company’s decisions leading up to the fatal MAX plane crashes to even greater public scrutiny.

Kin unhappy

The crashes occurred in Indonesia and Ethiopia within a five-month period and resulted in the death of 346 people.

The families of the victims have been demanding that Boeing face prosecution for these tragedies.

A lawyer representing some of the families has criticised it as a “sweetheart deal” and vowed to oppose it in court.

Disadvantage

A guilty plea could potentially jeopardise the company’s ability to secure lucrative government contracts with entities such as the US Defense Department and Nasa, although it may seek waivers.

The issue

Boeing will admit it knowingly made false representations to the Federal Aviation Administration about a key software feature used on the MAX at low speeds.

The Maneuvering Characteristics Augmentation System (MCAS) software automatically pushed the airplane’s nose down in certain conditions.

It was tied to the two fatal crashes.

This software saved Boeing money by requiring less intensive training for pilots.
